hints.content: Start by understanding the definition of a beautiful integer. It must have an equal count of even and odd digits, and it must be divisible by k.
Consider how to count the even and odd digits in a number. You can convert the number to a string and iterate through each character to check if it's even or odd.
Remember that even digits are 0, 2, 4, 6, 8, while odd digits are 1, 3, 5, 7, 9. This categorization will help you count them effectively.
Think about how you will loop through the range from low to high. You can use a simple for loop to iterate through each integer in this range.
While iterating through the range, check if the current number is divisible by k first. This will help you quickly eliminate numbers that cannot be beautiful.
If a number is divisible by k, proceed to count its even and odd digits. Keep track of these counts using two separate counters.
After counting the digits, check if the counts of even and odd digits are equal. If they are, you have found a beautiful integer.
Don't forget to maintain a counter to keep track of how many beautiful integers you find as you iterate through the range.
Consider edge cases, such as when low and high are the same. In this case, you only need to check one number.
Also, think about the case where k is greater than high. In such cases, no number in the range can be beautiful since they can't be divisible by k.
Remember that the range can go up to 10^9, so your solution needs to be efficient. Avoid unnecessary computations or nested loops.
You can optimize your solution by checking divisibility first before counting digits, as this will save time on non-divisible numbers.
Make sure to handle the input correctly, especially since low and high are guaranteed to be positive integers. Validate your inputs if needed.
Consider writing helper functions to separate the logic for counting even and odd digits. This will make your main function cleaner.
Finally, ensure that you return the count of beautiful integers as the output, as specified in the problem statement.

questionNotes: The range is inclusive, meaning both low and high are part of the range to check.
The counts of even and odd digits must be equal for a number to be considered beautiful.
The number must be divisible by k to meet the second condition of being beautiful.
Constraints indicate that low and high can be as large as 10^9, so efficiency is key.
k can be between 1 and 20, which is a small range, making it easier to check divisibility.
